title: How has ongoing rehabilitation changed for stroke care?
analysis_commentary:
High quality ongoing rehabilitation requires input from a number of key individuals to a patients' care. The NICE quality statement states that patients with stroke are offered a minimum of 45 minutes of each active therapy that is required, for a minimum of 5 days a week, at a level that enables the patient to meet their rehabilitation goals for as long as they are continuing to benefit from the therapy and are able to tolerate it.

Here we look at performance of occupational therapy, physiotherapy and speech & language therapy separately. Although there is no measure to look at these combined to accurately assess performance against the quality standard, these three measures can be used as a proxy. Overall, performance for speech & language therapy is lower compared to physiotherapy and occupational therapy; this is an average of 32.0% compared to an average of 65.3% for physiotherapy and 68.1% for occupational therapy. All measures increased performance over time, with the biggest improvement seen in occupational therapy which increased by 19.4% in the year.
data_source: Royal College of Physicians, Sentinel Stroke National Audit Programme (SSNAP)
